titles.title: Score without Parts (40 Drawings by Thoreau): Twelve Haiku

makers.displaymaker: John Cage, 1912–1992; born Los Angeles, CA; died New York, NY
Published by Crown Point Press, established 1962
Printed by Stephen Thomas, American, active 1975–1980
Printed by Lilah Toland, American, active 1978–1983

texts.textentryhtml: Perhaps the most influential composer of the postwar avantgarde, John Cage was a close friend and mentor to numerous visual artists, including Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns. After making this etching at the age of sixty-six, Cage became dedicated to printmaking for the remainder of his life. The image duplicates the composer’s conducting score for his 1974 musical composition Score (40 Drawings by Thoreau) and 23 Parts, inspired by the writings of American naturalist Henry David Thoreau (1817–1862). Here each of the twelve bars of the score has been divided into three sections of five, seven, and five measures, recalling the number of syllables in Japanese Haiku poetry. Cage has replaced conventional musical notation with small drawings of natural elements, such as seeds, animal tracks, and nests. Reproduced from Thoreau’s journal, these images were selected and sequenced at random by Cage with the aid of the I Ching, an ancient Chinese divination text.

In this work, Cage, who is among the most influential composers and conceptual artists of the postwar avant-garde, duplicates the score with which he conducted his 1974 composition Score (40 Drawings by Thoreau) and 23 Parts. Inspired by the writings of the American naturalist Henry David Thoreau (1817–1862), the artist replaced conventional musical notation with small drawings of natural elements—seeds, animal tracks, and nests—drawn from Thoreau’s journal, which Cage selected and sequenced at random with the aid of the I Ching, an ancient Chinese divination text. He then divided each of the twelve bars into three sections of five, seven, and five measures, transforming the score into a visual, sonorous, and experiential haiku.
texts.remarks: Migration and Material Alchemy: Marquand Mather Rotation
